Introduction

This article describes what great customer service looks like, and provides general principles of how support staff should operate to provide that good customer experience.

Support plays a vital part in ensuring that from early engagement with customers (usually via K3 consultants) during implementation, through to Production live steady state, and enhancing their system, customers receive great service which means that:

  • They remain customers
  • They buy more products and services
  • They are happy to provide great references to new customers/prospects

 

The principles in this article should also be extended to how the Support Team deal with partners and internal staff.

 

What Great Customer Service Looks Like to Customers

The following are what customers should expect and experience when interacting with the K3 Support Team:

  • Quick, caring response
  • Regular updates on open tickets
  • Knowledgeable staff
  • Proactive service - to be informed of issues from other customers which might affect them, or product updates
  • No passing of the buck (not being told that it's waiting for another internal team at K3 and given the impression that it's nothing to do with Support)
  • Customers don't have to explain the problem multiple times to different people
  • Receive honest responses (see more guidance below!)
  • Treated with respect (even if query or issue turns out to be spurious/wrong etc)
  • Easy to escalate if required and justified
  • Easy access to see my open tickets and statuses


 

Ten Principles of Delivering Great Customer Service

It is not always possible to fix or deliver everything as quickly as a customers might like. The following are general guiding principles of how Support Team members should conduct themselves to deliver the best customer satisfaction possible:


  1. Be polite, calm, and professional in all interactions with customers


  2. Empathise with the customers

    They may be under extreme pressure from senior people in their organisation to have something resolved quickly, even though you may not think it's important.
    Even if the customer is wrong, don't make them feel like they're wrong

  3. Provide regular updates even if there is no new update from another internal team you're waiting on

    There is a documented schedule of the minimum expected update frequency in Keeping Customers Updated

  4. Be responsible for calls you log or are assigned to

    Even if the next steps are waiting on someone else, chase up a response (internal or external) and do not use assignment to another internal team as an excuse to the customers.

    It's ok to say it's been passed/escalated to second or third line support because it gives an indication of how seriously we are treating something, but be clear that you are chasing those teams on the customer's behalf.

    Stick to personal pronouns such as "we" and "I", not "they" or "them" e.g. "We are investigating and expect to have an update by the end of today", not "They are investigating and expect to give us an update today"

    Make sure you pass a ticket onto another colleague if you are going on holiday etc

  5. Be helpful to other team members

    Team members have different experience levels - there's no such thing as a stupid question

    If a response comes in for a call which you don't own, but you know that the owner is not available or an action is required ASAP, then progress the ticket in your colleague's absence

    Respectfully help people out with process, prioritisation, or workload as required. Proactively asking someone if they would like help, or suggesting an alternative way of doing something (without being abrupt/telling them they're doing it all wrong!)

  6. If you promise something, make sure you do it, and do it when you say you will
    If something changes that means it won't be possible, let the customer know in advance (i.e. don't let them chase you when something's not done as they were expecting).

  7. Manage expectations - set expectations, but don't give unrealistic timeframes

    We often can't provide an estimated fix date/time at first, but we can provide expectations on when the next update is going to be

    If we give a time frame to provide an update, make contact well before the end of that time frame

    If there's a blocking issue internally, update the customer in a manner which is informing them of the problem, but without airing our dirty washing (so, truthful updates without necessarily explaining internal problems which are none of the customer's concern)

  8. It's ok to make a mistake if you were working to the best of your understanding and ability, but...

    Take steps to make sure it doesn't happen again

    Document the pitfall so that others don't make the same mistake

  9. Provide clear and accurate communication

    Read your own ticket update before sending to make sure it's clear and unambiguous.

    If you're not 100% sure about the accuracy of your communication, double check with the source (if applicable). If the update has come from another source, e.g. a software developer, then rephrase it to be friendly/understandable for the customer where applicable.

  10. Be commercially aware

    Don't spend a long time working on an issue which you think is not covered under the customer's contract - escalate to a Support Team manager

    Don't tell customers that something will only take "a few minutes" for example/ If it's chargeable, pass on to to a CSM as per Passing Sales Opportunities to CSMs to have a quote done properly in case we set the wrong expectation

    Refer to What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it

Initial Categorisation and Prioritisation is key

See the principles on Setting Case Urgency, Impact and Priority  The initial category and priority dictates how we deal with the ticket and ensures that we work on the highest priority issues affecting tradign first, bu don't forget the lower priority ones.

One call/request one ticket

Tickets can become complicated and hard to understand if they consist of several different requests, and makes the SLA impossible to measure (e.g. a customer might complain that a ticket's been open for a long time, but actually we resolved the original issue quite quickly)

 

Any time you receive a call or email regarding a new issue, a new ticket must be logged.

  • Don't let customers add more issues to same ticket (e.g. on an email chain) - otherwise we get complaints that ticket X has been open for 8 weeks when actually we solved the original issue much sooner 
  • Customer calls about a ticket that was previously resolved - Open a new ticket as it is a new issue.
  • If another customer calls about an on-going problem where one or moe Incidents are already created - Create a new ticket
  • If you get a call about an on-going case - Make a note in the existing ticket (don’t open a new ticket)

 

Indicators that a ticket includes more than one request is that there are >50 comments/updates (which makes them unreadable for others and hard to digest), and if the original issue was solved or not


Keep Tickets Updated

  • Respond to customer updates and requests for more information according to the Next Response SLA - see Keeping Customers Updated and Next Response SLA 
  • Support tickets should be updated with all major investigation info and all updates to customers included (regardless of whether you called or emailed the customer).
  • Ticket updates should be made throughout the ticket lifecycle, not just at the opening and closing of a ticket.

 

Why?

  • Colleagues are able to check on progress if required (e.g. the ticket owner is away or if there’s an escalation).
  • Customers do not escalate tickets due to a lack of update/contact from Support.

 

Incidents

(Any disruption to service or reduction in quality of a service)


If there is a P1, please follow this process: How to handle a P1  

If this affects multiple customers and is a P1, consult Major Incident handling 

Perform thorough troubleshooting. Put appropriate info in the ticket. Example things to consider:

  • Restart the service (POS, Backoffice, PC)
  • Are other stores impacted?
    • (The staff may not know this. Many will have internal communication channels and can quickly find out for you)
    • Try log on teamviewer on a different store and test.
  • When did the Incident occur?
  • Has it happened before?

 

Troubleshooting steps so next level resolver can see what has been done - example below:

Step1: Restarted PC

Step2: Cleared Cache

Step3: Unplugged all cables and plugged back in 


When to Resolve a Ticket?

  • If you request information and they don't respond, then if you've chased them two more times and have no response, then close the ticket (normal expected timeframe - 2 weeks)
  • If the customer confirms that you have provided a solution/fix, then close it.
  • If you do not receive any confirmation, then you can close a ticket two weeks after providing a resolution (during the two weeks, make sure the ticket is set to a status which shows everyone that we're waiting for the customer to respond)
    • Workbooks - close immediately then reopen within 2 weeks (after that, new ticket)
    • CRM - close immediately then reopen within 2 weeks (after that, new ticket)
      • UNLESS customer is using the CRM portal, in which case set to "Awaiting Customer Closure"

 


Problem Record (Tracker ticket)

A problem record needs to be created by a Support Manager for any issues which affect multiple customers - see How to link / use a Tracker ticket if multiple customers report the same issue

text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Why? How Quickly Should We Respond to Customer Updates? How Often Should We Proactively Update Customers? Tickets should be kept updated as per "Keep tickets updated" on General Ticket Management Why? No news is bad news! Keeping customers updated is critical because even if not much has happened on a ticket, or not much progress has been made, updating customers with even a "we're still working on it" at least makes them think that we've not forgotten about them/their ticket. text: To maintain/increase customer's perceptions of our care for them: 1. Ask if there’s anything else we can help with when on the phone to customers. title: Setting Ticket Urgency, Impact and Priority
text: The general principles of assessing the priority of a ticket apply regardless of the system and are documented in the Service Level Agreement (SLA). Impact and Urgency Impact is a measure of the effect of an Incident. Urgency is a measure of how long it will be until an Incident has a significant business impact. The definitions of Urgency and Impact are and copied below: Rating Urgency Impact Low A resolution can be scheduled for when is mutually convenient. Superficial and does not materially impact functionality. Medium Needs to be addressed soon to prevent any further deterioration. Impacts functionality, but continued use is possible. High Requires immediate attention. Affects the majority of users and/or prevents use of the system. Only Incidents have Urgency and Impact; Service or Change Requests only have Urgency Priority The table below defines the priority levels applied to Incidents which is calculated from the Urgency and Impact. The priority of an Incident may change throughout its duration. For example, a Priority 2 Incident may be upgraded to Priority 1 if an Incident affecting some users spreads to all users; or a Priority 1 Incident could be downgraded to Priority 2 if a Workaround is provided in advance of a permanent fix. Urgency Impact Low Medium High Low P5 P4 P3 Medium P4 P3 P2 High P3 P2 P1 Tickets which are not Incidents (examples include an enquiry on how to do something, or an enhancement request) will be assigned a Priority according to their Urgency only i.e. a priority of P3, P4, or P5 for Urgency of High, Medium, or Low respectively. Examples The circumstances of the same Incident determine its Impact or Urgency. An example is where a store has four Point of Sale (POS) solutions and one develops a fault which renders it inoperable (hardware or software): During a quiet period when customer numbers are low, this might have an Impact of “Medium” and an Urgency of “Medium” (resulting in a Priority of “P3”). If the same Incident were to occur in a very busy period, the Impact would still be “Medium” (because other POS solutions are operable), but the Urgency may be “High” (resulting in a Priority of “P2”). Note that in the extremely unlikely event that all POS solutions were inoperable in a location, this would be a High Impact and High Urgency Incident, resulting in a Priority of “P1”. What is a Site / Location? A site / location is a trading outlet. Therefore if a business has three areas it does business from in the same location (e.g. cafe, souvenir store, ticket sales), they should be treated as a whole Site / Location. So if their souvenir store only has one till, then if that goes down, it's a P1. The same applies for a website - it should be considered a separate location/site, so if a website we are responsible does not work, then it's a P1 as that whole "Site" is not able to trade.

title: Taking Care Of, and Editing Customer Data
text: Taking Care of Customer Data You should already be aware of General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) - our policies can be found on Policies (sharepoint.com), but in Support we need also need to be aware of some of the principles in System and Organization Controls (SOC) (even though we are not audited for it). Customer data, particularly financial (and medical) has extra protection in law. If a copy of customer data is needed to be transferred to K3 equipment to investigate an issue: The best method to use is TeamViewer. If TeamViewer is not possible for any reason, then use a K3 FTP site where available. As a last resort you can use an online file transfer site but only if the data is encrypted or at least password protected by the transfer site. Make sure that you always ask the customer to encrypt/password protect the file before transfer if we are not using TeamViewer to get the data ourselves (TV transfers are encrypted as per End-to-end encryption (E2EE) | TeamViewer ). Once we have the data, it should be kept encrypted, and when you unencrypt it to use it (e.g. to load into a database), delete the unencrypted as soon as possible, and once the issue has been resolved, all co[pied should be permanently deleted from K3 equipment Key Rule for Everyone, Every Time We should not transmit or store unencrypted customer data Changing Customer Data Key Rule for Everyone, Every Time If any situation requires a change to customer's live data, then you must have the customer's written approval (in the ticket) before you make the change. Further guidance The above does not apply to configuration data/settings changes. If you are not sure if the customer has authority to make data changes (especially if via a phone call), then ask them if they have authority, and if you or they are still not sure, ask them to check with their management before proceeding (and check with a Support Manager if you're not sure). If you think the data change is high risk, consult a colleague before going ahead. Ideally you will take a back-up of the customer's data before making a change. Give a high-level explanation of what data is being changed, and why e.g. "Please confirm that you approve changing the transaction references on all transactions affected by the system crashing. The risk is low of any unintended consequences of doing this". If you are on a phone call with a customer, and you are also logged on to their system, and need to make a data change, if it's a real emergency and can't wait for customer approval, then you must get their verbal confirmation and tell them that you will email them afterwards from the support ticket confirming what you have done, and requesting that they respond to confirm they were aware and are happy with the data change. This is designed to keep the customer, you, and K3 safe from any consequences (which can be severe) of making a data change

title: How to handle a P1
text: If a P1 is happening for multiple customers with the same underlying cause, please refer to Major Incident Management . If there is a P1 which has been verified by First Line Support as a customer being unable to trade in a location (e.g. coffee shop, website), then this ticket becomes top priority for everyone involved. If FLS cannot solve it, contact SLS and check who’s going to work on it and assign to them. The FLS person must not just pass the ticket to SLS - they need to make sure someone in SLS is aware of it immediately (so message them, check for a response, call them, talk to them if in the same office!) The SLS person should stop working on anything else (obviously there might be some exceptions such as in the middle of an upgrade or phone call, but then another SLS should be dealing with the P1 anyway if available). Dialogue between FLS and SLS should continue – FLS checking if SLS need any help updating the customer for example, or at least keeping an eye on progress. If a valid P1 is raised during normal hours and continues after supported hours, then we would normally expect the ticket owner to carry on working on it out of normal hours or handover to someone who can. TOIL can be claimed if a significant amount of effort after hours is required (except management usually can’t claim!) If a P1 is raised via the portal, then a Teams message is sent to the relevant country's chat. If it's raised by phone, then by definition one of us knows about it, and if it's raised via email, then again, one of us has reviewed the email and changed it from the default P4 to a P1, so the above procedure can be followed ASAP
